claim: Someone born in the year 2000 is 20 years old in 2010

supporting.text: A person born in the year 2000 would be 10 years old in 2010, not 20.

attacks.text: A person born in the year 2000 would be 10 years old in 2010, not 20.
If the claim is interpreted as a typographical error and meant to say '2020' instead of '2010', then the statement would be correct.
Typographical errors are not valid interpretations of claims; the original statement must be evaluated as written.
In some cultures or contexts, age is calculated differently, such as counting the year of birth as age 1.
The Gregorian calendar and standard age calculation methods are the globally accepted norm, making alternative methods irrelevant in this context.

supporting.text: Basic arithmetic shows that subtracting 2000 from 2010 results in 10 years.

attacks.text: Basic arithmetic shows that subtracting 2000 from 2010 results in 10 years.
The claim assumes the person was born at the very start of 2000, but if they were born at the end of the year, they would not have turned 10 yet in 2010.
Even if the person was born at the end of 2000, they would still be 9 years old for most of 2010, but would turn 10 by the end of the year.
The claim might be interpreted as referring to the age at the exact moment of birth, which would make the person 0 years old in 2000 and 10 years old in 2010.
Interpreting the claim as referring to the exact moment of birth is overly literal and not how age is commonly understood.

supporting.text: Age is calculated by counting the number of full years since birth, which would be 10 in this case.

attacks.text: Age is calculated by counting the number of full years since birth, which would be 10 in this case.
The claim might be considering the person's age at the end of the year 2010, making them 10 years old.
If the person was born early in the year 2000, they would have already turned 10 by 2010, supporting the claim.
However, if they were born late in the year 2000, they would still be 9 years old for most of 2010.
The claim might be a typo, intending to say '2020' instead of '2010'.
Typos are common, but without additional context, this remains speculative.

supporting.text: The claim contradicts the universally accepted method of calculating age based on birth year and current year.

attacks.text: The claim contradicts the universally accepted method of calculating age based on birth year and current year.
The claim might be interpreted as a typo, where '2010' was intended to be '2020'.
Even if it was a typo, the original claim as stated is still incorrect and misleading.
Some cultures calculate age differently, such as counting the time in the womb as the first year.
Such cultural practices are not universally accepted and do not apply to standard age calculations.
